official-title.#text: To expand the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006 to increase accountability and transparency in Federal spending, and for other purposes.

attestation-date.#text: Passed the House of Representatives November 18, 2013.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Sec. 3. Amendments to the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006.
Sec. 4. Pilot program to evaluate consolidated recipient reporting.
Sec. 6. American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 amendments.
Sec. 7. Disaster Relief Appropriations Act of 2013 amendments.
Sec. 8. Executive agency accounting and other financial management reports and plans.
Sec. 9. Limits and transparency for conference and travel spending.

text.#text: The purposes of this Act are to—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: by disclosing direct Federal agency expenditures and linking Federal contract, loan, and grant spending information to programs of Federal agencies in order to enable taxpayers and policy makers to track Federal spending more effectively;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006

text.#text: expand the
provide consistent, reliable, and searchable Government-wide spending data that is displayed accurately for taxpayers and policy makers on USASpending.gov;
analyze Federal spending data to proactively prevent waste, fraud, abuse, and improper payments;
simplify reporting for entities receiving Federal funds by streamlining reporting requirements and reducing compliance costs while improving transparency; and
improve the quality of data submitted to USASpending.gov by holding Federal agencies accountable for the completeness and accuracy of the data submitted.

header.#text: Department of the treasury requirements for data standards

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and the heads of Federal agencies, shall establish Government-wide financial data standards for Federal funds, which shall—

text.#text: The

include common data elements, such as codes, unique award identifiers, and fields, for financial and payment information required to be reported by Federal agencies and entities receiving Federal funds, including identifiers for Federal awards and entities receiving Federal awards;
to the extent reasonable and practicable, ensure interoperability and incorporate—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , such as the International Organization for Standardization;

text.#text: common data elements developed and maintained by an international voluntary consensus standards body, as defined by the
common data elements developed and maintained by Federal agencies with authority over contracting and financial assistance, such as the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council; and
common data elements developed and maintained by accounting standards organizations; and
include data reporting standards that—
incorporate a widely accepted, nonproprietary, searchable, platform-independent computer-readable format;
are consistent with and implement applicable accounting principles;
are capable of being continually upgraded as necessary;

are structured to specifically support the reporting of financial and performance-related data, such as that any data produced, regardless of reporting need or software used for creation or consumption, is consistent and comparable across reporting situations;
establish, for each data point, a standard method of conveying the reporting period, reporting entity, unit of measure, and other associated attributes; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013

text.#text: incorporate nonproprietary standards in effect on the date of enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall issue guidance on the data standards established under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to Federal agencies not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006/s:2/ss:e/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

text.#text: The

review the financial reporting required by Federal agencies for Federal award recipients to consolidate financial reporting and reduce duplicative financial reporting and compliance costs for recipients;
request input from Federal award recipients to reduce duplicative financial reporting, especially from State and local governments and institutions of higher education;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , provide guidance to the heads of Federal agencies regarding how to simplify the reporting requirements for Federal award recipients to consolidate financial reporting, reduce duplicative reporting, and reduce compliance costs, as appropriate; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013

text.#text: not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of the

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall develop and test information technology resources and oversight mechanisms to enhance the transparency of and detect and remediate waste, fraud, and abuse in Federal spending for Inspectors General.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall maintain a website informing the public of its activities to identify waste, fraud, and abuse and increase transparency of Federal funds to provide support for Inspectors General.

header.#text: Pilot program to evaluate consolidated recipient reporting

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall establish a pilot program relating to reporting by recipients of Federal funds (in this section referred to as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the

quote.#tail: ) for the purpose of increasing financial transparency to—

text.#text: display the full cycle of Federal funds;
improve the accuracy of Federal financial data; and
develop recommendations for reducing reporting required of recipients of Federal funds by consolidating and automating financial reporting requirements across the Federal Government.
The pilot program shall—
include a combination of recipients of Federal contracts, grants, and subawards, the aggregate value of which is not less than $1,000,000,000;
include a diverse group of recipients of Federal awards; and
to the extent practicable, include recipients that receive Federal awards from multiple programs across multiple agencies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: reports on the finances of the selected Federal awards.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

text.#text: Each recipient of Federal funds participating in the pilot program shall submit to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: under the pilot program shall be made publicly available and searchable on the website established under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

text.#text: All the information collected by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 2 of the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006/s:2
usc/31/6101/note
Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

text.#text: The pilot program shall terminate on the date that is 3 years after the date on which the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013/s:4/ss:e
Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the pilot program, which shall include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date on which the pilot program terminates under
a description of financial data collected under the pilot program, the accuracy of the data provided, and the cost to collect the data from recipients; and
recommendations for—
consolidating some or all aspects of Federal financial reporting to reduce the costs to recipients of Federal funds;
automating some or all aspects of Federal financial reporting to increase efficiency and reduce the costs to recipients of Federal funds; and
improving financial transparency.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013/s:4/ss:f

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall determine whether to authorize the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Director of the Office of Management and Budget

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to extend the recipient reporting requirements of the pilot program to all Federal funds. The
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall begin requiring Government-wide recipient reporting at the start of the fiscal year that commences after the fiscal year during which such authorization is granted, and under such terms and conditions that the Board shall determine, in consultation with the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board

header.#text: Limits and transparency for conference and travel spending

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/5/57
usc-chapter/5/5711

header.#text: Limits and transparency for conference and travel spending

text.#text: Each agency shall post on the public website of that agency detailed information on any presentation made by any employee of that agency at a conference (except to the extent the head of an agency excludes such information for reasons of national security or information described under
the prepared text of any verbal presentation made; and
any visual, digital, video, or audio materials presented, including photographs, slides, and audio-visual recordings.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , an agency may not expend more than $500,000 to support a single conference.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/5/5712/a/2/B

text.#text: Except as provided under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for a specific conference after making a determination that the expenditure is justified as the most cost-effective option to achieve a compelling purpose. The head of an agency shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on any waiver granted under this subparagraph, including the justification for such waiver.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/5/5712/a/2/A

text.#text: The head of an agency may waive the limitation under

Nothing in this paragraph shall be construed to preclude an agency from receiving financial support or other assistance from a private entity to pay or defray the costs of a conference the total cost of which exceeds $500,000.

header.#text: Limits on amount expended on a conference

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: determines that attendance for such employees is in the national interest, or the head of the agency determines that attendance for such employees is critical to the agency’s mission. The
and the head of an agency shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on any waiver granted under this subsection, including the justification for such waiver.

text.#text: An agency may not pay the travel expenses for more than 50 employees of that agency who are stationed in the United States, for any international conference, unless the

At the beginning of each quarter of each fiscal year, each agency shall post on the public website of that agency a report on each conference that costs more than $10,000 for which the agency paid travel expenses during the preceding 3 months that includes—

header.#text: Reporting on travel and conference expenses required

text.#text: the itemized expenses paid by the agency, including travel, lodging, and meal expenses, and any other agency expenditures to otherwise support the conference;
the primary sponsor of the conference;
the location of the conference;
the date of the conference;
a brief explanation of how the participation of employees from such agency at the conference advanced the mission of the agency;
the title of any employee, or any individual who is not a Federal employee, whose travel expenses or other conference expenses were paid by the agency;
the total number of individuals whose travel expenses or other conference expenses were paid by the agency; and
in the case of a conference for which that agency was the primary sponsor, a statement that—
describes the cost to the agency of selecting the specific conference venue;
describes why the location was selected, including a justification for such selection;
demonstrates the cost efficiency of the location;
provides a cost benefit analysis of holding a conference rather than conducting a teleconference; and

describes any financial support or other assistance from a private entity used to pay or defray the costs of the conference, and for each case where such support or assistance was used, the head of the agency shall include a certification that there is no conflict of interest resulting from such support or assistance.
Each report posted on the public website under
be in a searchable electronic format; and
remain on that website for at least 5 years after the date of posting.
